awd_titl_txt: Mechanics-based Service-life Prediction of Natural-Fiber Composites
awd_abstract_narration:
With applications in the automotive, packaging, and construction industries, natural-fiber composites have gained in relevance over the past few decades as sustainable alternatives to synthetic-fiber composite materials. However, widespread application of natural-fiber composites remains limited due to concerns regarding their durability in high-humidity and wet environments. Previous moisture-related durability research has been empirical in nature. This award will support fundamental research to model the environmentally assisted degradation of natural-fiber composites. The mechanics-based modeling approaches will be used to elucidate relationships between composite composition, hygrothermal exposure, mechanical degradation, and environmental sustainability. The research activities will advance the science and engineering of materials that are fully biorenewable and economically viable on a global scale. The complementary education and outreach efforts will help foster a more inclusive generation of female engineers who will become technical leaders in engineering mechanics and materials sustainability.
 
The primary objective of this research is to use micromechanics to predict moisture- and frost-induced damage in both short- and continuous-fiber natural-fiber composites that are exposed to fluctuating hygrothermal conditions. In addition to composite synthesis, the experimental work includes meso- and nano-scale mechanical testing to correlate moisture content and temperature with reductions in mechanical properties of fibers, matrices, and composites thereof. The computational work includes formulation of diffusion-based moisture transport models; formulation of micromechanical damage models to account for internal strains from fiber softening and expansion; and model validation using data obtained from the accelerated weathering of composite samples. Once calibrated with experimental data, the mechanics-based service-life models will be used to predict in-situ degradation and to estimate functional obsolescence (end of life) in several applications in a variety of geographic locations. These service-life estimates will be integrated into a probabilistic lifecycle assessment modeling framework to calculate true environmental impacts across variable spatial and temporal domains.

por.por_cntn:
Natural fiber composites (NFCs) have been suggested as a sustainable alternative to synthetic petroleum-based fiber-reinforced polymers (FRP) for construction (and other) applications. Although NFCs have many favorable attributes, such as good mechanical properties, bio-renewability, and low cost, the inherent hydrophilicity of lignocellulosic fibers makes NFCs susceptible to both moisture- and freeze-thaw-induced deterioration. As such, there is an identified need to more fully understand and better predict response of NFCs to in-service environmental aggressors (e.g., high relative humidity and freezing temperatures) to confidently promote widespread use of NFCs and meet the emerging demand. 

This project investigated the hygromechanical response of NFCs for in-service use by employing different computational and experimental methods across length scales. The primary outcomes of this work include (1) nanoscale mechanical characterization of lignocellulosic polymers (i.e., cellulose and lignin), (2) moisture kinetics and mechanical characterization of low fiber NFCs (i.e., hemp-polyethylene, wood-polypropylene, and wood-high density polyethylene), (3) the utility of cross laminate plate theory (CLPT) to predict the mechanical response of laminate transparent wood composites (TWCs), and (4) micromechanical modeling to determine the onset of moisture-induced damage for different wood polymer composites (WPCs) when exposed in-service relative humidity conditions. More specifically, this project has contributed the following key research findings. The elastic modulus of lignin was shown to decrease as moisture content increased, and cyclic measurements substantiated that the elastic stiffness of lignin fully rebounds upon moisture desorption. The viscoelastic loss tangent of cellulose nanofibrils, which was measured and reported for the first time, does not vary in the transverse direction over the length of nanofibrils even in the presence of kinked defects. For NFC formulations investigated in this work, results showed that there is a fiber volume fraction threshold between 15% and 30% at which freeze-thaw conditions further exacerbate moisture-induced damage. For laminated TWCs, results confirmed that the mechanical behavior is well described using CLPT, which demonstrates that lamination is a viable technique to scale up the size while maintaining adequate mechanical properties of TWCs. Finally, modelled results showed that a commercially available WPC would incur damage when placed in a commonplace 40% to 45% relative humidity environment. However, if the fiber volume fraction was lowered from ~46% to ~27%, the model predicts that the WPC would be moisture-resistant.

 

The results from this project have advanced the fundamental scientific understanding of the relationships between NFC material (mechanical) response, environmental (hygrothermal) exposure, and mechanical degradation by combining contemporary mechanics with the state-of-the-art mechanical testing. NFCs will comprise an increasing fraction of the application space as the global market grows from ~$4.5 billion in 2016 to ~$11 billion by 2024. This work provided key contributions to understanding the behavior of NFCs to meet performance expectations while in-service. Thus, NFCs will be well suited to provide not only a sustainable but also a resilient building material for construction applications. Moreover, results from this work encourage more widespread use of environmental benign and readily available biobased materials, which aim to reduce environmental impacts and progress towards a closed-loop material lifecycle. Finally, this project has provided a unique opportunity for women interested in engineering mechanics to build technical expertise and become scholars and leaders in the field of engineering mechanics.
